National Institute of Technology, Catalysis, Biocatalysis and Chemical Processes Division Rio de Janeiro 20081-312 Brazil This work studies the effect of oxygen vacancies in a silica-doped ceria support on the mechanism of HDO reaction of phenol, m-cresol, xylenol and anisole over Pd-based catalysts. Increasing the silica content increased the density of oxygen vacancies due to the decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size. The addition of silica also promoted the reaction rate for HDO of phenolic compounds, whereas the rate for HDO of anisole remained approximately constant. These results revealed that the oxygen vacancies promoted the cleavage of the C-OH bond of phenolic molecules. Moreover, the presence of an electron donor on the aromatic ring reduces the energy barrier necessary for the cleavage of the Carom – OH bond. In the case of anisole, this molecule adsorbs on the Ce cations close to the metallic particles and then, the variation of the concentration of oxygen vacancies does not affect the rate of HDO. Graphical Abstract Keywords HDO m-cresol Anisole Xylenol Oxygen vacancies Silica-doped ceria Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass can be converted into biofuels by different technologies [1]. The conversion of biomass into bio-oil through fast pyrolysis is considered a promising route for producing renewable fuels [2]. Bio-oil is typically a very complex mixture composed of several organic compounds, including acids, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, sugars, furans, and phenolic compounds. Due to the presence of these oxygenates and water, bio-oil has a poor quality as a fuel and is thermally and chemically unstable. Consequently, bio-oil must be upgraded to be used as a fuel in combustion engines. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of bio-oil is considered a promising technology for bio-oil upgrading, in which molecularly bound oxygen is removed in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst [3]. Designing an efficient catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) requires an in-depth understanding of the reaction pathways involved. Due to the complex chemical composition of bio-oil, researchers often employ model compounds that represent key structural classes found in biomass-derived molecules. These model systems facilitate the investigation of reaction pathways and kinetics, as well as provide insights into the specific functions of heterogeneous catalyst components. The bio-oil obtained from the fast pyrolysis of the lignin fraction of the biomass contains functionalized phenols as the main constituents. Therefore, compounds such as phenol [4,5], cresols [6,7], anisole [8,9], and guaiacol [10,11], which have hydroxyl and methoxy functional groups linked to the aromatic ring, have been extensively used as model compounds representative of lignin for catalyst development. The HDO of those molecules has been investigated over a variety of supported catalysts [12–14]. It has been reported that the support plays an important role in the HDO reaction mechanism of those phenolic molecules [15–17]. In the HDO of phenol and m-cresol for example, the acid sites of the support may promote the dehydration followed by hydrogenation and formation of deoxygenated products [18,19]. It has also been proposed that the oxophilic sites of supports such as ZrO2, TiO2 and Nb2O5, represented by the Zr3 + /Zr4+, Ti3+/Ti4+ and Nb4+/Nb5+ cations, strongly interact with the oxygen atom of the phenolic molecule, which reduces the energy required for the cleavage of the C-O bond, promoting direct deoxygenation [20–22]. The deoxygenation activity has also been attributed to the oxygen vacancies of metal oxides such as WOx, ceria and ceria-mixed oxides [23–26]. Wang et al. [23] proposed that oxygen vacancies on the WOx near the Pt particles are the sites for the direct C-O bond breaking for the HDO of m-cresol on Pt-WOx/C catalysts. According to Marlowe et al. [24], the preferential decoration of well-coordinated sites on Pt nanoparticles by reduced WOx species also contributes for the suppression of aromatic ring hydrogenation. Cerium oxide has a high oxygen exchange capacity, which is due to the ability of cerium to reversibly change its oxidation states between Ce4+ and Ce3+ by taking or releasing oxygen [27]. The reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ is simultaneously accompanied by the creation of oxygen vacancies to keep the charge balance of the crystal lattice (intrinsic vacancies). The addition of dopants to ceria can promote the oxygen mobility due to the formation of a solid solution [28]. Zirconia has been the most studied dopant, but rare earth elements such as Pr4+, La3+, Gd3+, Y3+ have also been investigated. In the case of using tri-valent oxides as dopants, the oxygen vacancies are formed due to the substitution of Ce4+ for a cation with lower oxidation state (extrinsic vacancies). However, the effective role of the oxygen vacancies on the HDO reaction is not clear yet and contradictory results have been reported in the literature [15,25,29]. Schimming et al. [25] investigated the performance of a series of CexZr1-xO2 catalysts with different Ce/Zr ratios without reduced metal sites for the HDO of guaiacol. The results demonstrated that the catalytic activity depended on the concentration of oxygen vacancies. According to the authors, the oxygen vacancies promoted the activation of the C–O bond and the deoxygenation of guaiacol molecule. The addition of Zr reduces the crystallite size, creating more active sites at the strained edges at the boundaries of smaller crystallites [30]. de Souza et al. [15] studied the role of the oxygen vacancies for the HDO of phenol over Pd supported on different oxides. An IR spectroscopic study of adsorbed CO demonstrated that Pd/CeO2 and Pd/CeZrO2 showed the highest number of oxygen vacancies compared to Pd/ZrO2 and Pd/TiO2 catalysts, whereas they exhibited the lowest activity to deoxygenation and selectivity to benzene among all catalysts studied. A similar result was obtained by Teles et al. [29], who carried out in situ XANES and XPS to measure the amount of Ce3+ on Pd/CexZr1-xO2 catalysts (x = 0.0; 0.10; 0.25; 0.50; 0.75; 1.0) reduced under pure H2 at 300 °C. Increasing the Zr content, the fraction of Ce3+ continuously increased until x = 0.75 and then decreased. On the other hand, the selectivity to benzene remained constant up to x = 0.5 and thus, it increased. These results suggest that there is no direct correlation between the density of oxygen vacancies and the deoxygenation activity of this series of supported Pd catalysts. In fact, doping ceria with zirconia is not a good strategy to study the effect of oxygen vacancies on the deoxygenation capacity of the support because it is not possible to distinguish between the effect of oxygen vacancies and the oxophilicity of Zr cations, since both can directly influence the selectivity to deoxygenated products [9,15]. However, the formation of a solid solution by doping ceria is not the only way to improve its redox properties. The addition of silica to ceria may also increase the oxygen mobility of ceria [31]. Furthermore, SiO2 is considered to be an inert support for HDO reactions [9,15], allowing the role of oxygen vacancies in the support to be evaluated separately. However, silica-doped ceria supported catalysts have not yet been tested for HDO of phenolic molecules. Therefore, the aim of this work is to investigate the role of oxygen vacancies of silica-doped ceria supports on the mechanism of HDO of phenol, m-cresol, xylenol and anisole over Pd-based catalysts. The selected molecules encompass the primary oxygenated functionalities found in bio-oil derived from lignin pyrolysis: the −OH group (in phenolic compounds) and −OCH3 (in anisole). Then, unraveling the mechanism for the elimination of each functional group provides valuable insights for the design of suitable catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of bio-oil derived from lignin. The oxygen vacancies were created by the addition of different amounts of silica to ceria. The relationship between the HDO reaction rate and the selectivity to deoxygenated products with the density of oxygen vacancies is discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The preparation of CeO2-SiO2 support (SiCeO2) followed the method described by Ribeiro et al. [32]. Initially, a solution containing (NH4)2.Ce(NO3)6·6 H2O (Aldrich 98 %) and NH4OH (1 mol/L) was prepared in order to obtain a 1:10 Ce4+/NH3 molar ratio. Then, SiO2 (Aerosil 200 –Degussa) was solubilized in a solution containing sodium hydroxide at 100 °C for 30 min, and the resulting solution was added to the one containing the cerium precursor. The precipitate was washed at pH = 7 and dried at 110 °C for 24 h. The samples were calcined at 500 °C for 5 h under air flow. The prepared samples contained different SiO2 contents and were designed as xSiCeO2 (x = 0; 2; 6; 10 wt% SiO2). The catalysts with nominal Pd loading of 2 wt% were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the supports with an aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 (Umicore). After impregnation, the powder was dried in air at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 400 °C (2 °C/min) for 3 h under synthetic air flow (50 mL/min). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition of each sample was determined using a Wavelength Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence Spectrometer (WD-XRF) S8 Tiger (Bruker) with a rhodium tube operated at 4 kW. The analyses were performed with the samples (300 mg) in powder form using a semi-quantitative method (QUANT-EXPRES/Bruker). Specific surface areas of the samples were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer by N2 adsorption at −196 °C. Initially, the sample (300 mg) was pre-treated under vacuum overnight at 350°C. The specific surface was calculated by BET equation and the pore size distribution was determined by BJH method. The morphology was studied by field-emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JSM 2100 F/JEOL) in TEM mode and scanning-TEM (STEM) mode. The spatial chemical composition distribution was analyzed by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) with a silicon-drift detector. The samples were prepared by dropping the suspension of the catalysts onto Cu TEM grids with a thin carbon layer as support and dried in air at room temperature. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) over a 2θ range between 10 and 80º at a scan rate of 0.04 °/step and a scan time of 1 s/step. The acid properties of the catalysts were investigated by cyclohexanol dehydration probe reaction. The cyclohexanol dehydration reaction was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure and 543 K. Prior to the reaction, the fresh catalyst was reduced in situ under pure hydrogen (60 mL/min) at 573 K for 1 h. The used catalysts were not exposed to air before starting the cyclohexanol reaction. The reactant mixture was obtained by flowing He (30 mL/min) through a saturator containing cyclohexanol, which was maintained at 336 K. The reaction products were analyzed by GCMS (Agilent Technologies 7890 A/5975 C) using an HP innowax capillary column and a flame-ionization detector (FID). The dehydration rate was calculated by the sum of cyclohexene, cyclohexane, and benzene yields. The Oxygen Storage Capacity (OSC) and Oxygen Storage Complete Capacity (OSCC) were determined by using a quartz fixed-bed reactor placed in a furnace, which was connected to a Porapak column and a TCD detector. They are simple and effective methods widely used to determine the concentration of oxygen vacancies at catalyst surface [25,33,34]. Both procedures involve an initial treatment of the catalyst (20–50 mg) with pure hydrogen starting from room temperature to 300 °C, with a temperature increase of 5 °C/min. Then, the sample is purged with He (30 mL/min) until obtain a stable baseline. Then, pulses of pure O2 are carried out over the sample until no further uptake being detected (peaks of approximately equal area). The consumption of O2 was determined by analyzing the area under the respective peaks recorded by the TCD detector. It was assumed that each O2 molecule saturated two oxygen vacancies and the theoretical content of O2 to oxidize metallic Pd on the catalysts was subtracted. For the OSCC measurements [35], after catalyst reduction and purge, the samples are completely oxidized by 10 pulses of O2. After that, pulses of CO are injected up to the maximum reduction of the sample. The consumption of CO as well as the CO2 formed are determined from the area of the corresponding peaks obtained with the TCD detector. The OSCC values are calculated from the CO2 production instead of CO uptake, due to the possibility to form carbonate species during the CO pulses. In situ XAS experiments were performed at the XDS-W09A beamline of the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Source (LNLS/CNPEM, Campinas). Typically, wafers containing pressed mixtures of the sample with boron nitride as a binder were then placed into a sample holder located inside a quartz tubular reactor. XANES spectra were successively recorded around the Ce LIII-edge (E0 = 5.723 keV), while the sample underwent the following treatment: (i) reduction under a 5 % H2/He mixture from 25 to 300 °C (10 K/min), remaining at this temperature for 1 h. Data reduction was made using the ATHENA software package. The background subtracted, normalized XANES spectra were then truncated over a suitable energy range (80 eV above the absorption edge). The fractions of Ce4+ and Ce3+ during the reduction treatment of the sample were estimated by linear combination of normalized Ce LIII edge XANES spectra (LC-XANES) within the 5.70–5.76 keV energy range, using CeO2 and Ce(OH)CO3 as references for Ce4+ and Ce3+, respectively. The cyclohexane dehydrogenation was used as a structurally-insensitive probe reaction to estimate the Pd dispersion of the catalysts. This methodology was successfully used before [36]. It is known that H2 and CO may not only chemisorb on the active metals but also on some metal oxides supports such as ceria that may undergo partial reduction [37]. In this case, hydrogen dissociated on the metal form Type II hydroxyl groups, which can adsorb CO, resulting in the formation of carbonate and formate species, as revealed by DRIFTS experiments of CO adsorbed on Pd/CeO2 catalyst [15]. In addition, bulk Pd hydrides can be formed [38], leading to an overestimation of the dispersion. Therefore, dehydrogenation of cyclohexane was used as an alternative method for determining metal dispersion. Prior to the reaction, the samples were reduced under pure hydrogen at 300 °C for 1 h. Then the cyclohexane dehydrogenation reaction was performed at 270 °C. The reaction mixture was obtained by flowing hydrogen through a saturator containing liquid cyclohexane at 12 °C. thereby producing a hydrogen/cyclohexane molar ratio of 13.2. The reaction products were analyzed on an Agilent GCMS (7890 A/5975 C), equipped with an HP-Innowax capillary column and a flame-ionization detector (FID). To correlate the rate of cyclohexane dehydrogenation and Pd dispersion, CO uptake on Pd/SiO2 and Pd/Al2O3 (i.e., nonreducible supports) were used as references for calibration. The Pd particle size was calculated from the Pd dispersion using Eq. 1 [36]: (1) dPd = 1.12/DPd 2.3 Catalytic activity The HDO of model molecules (phenol, m-cresol, xylenol and anisole) was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor, in gas phase at atmospheric pressure and 300 °C. The samples were mixed with silicon carbide (mSiC/mcatalyst = 3.0) to avoid hot spot formation or flow channeling. Previous calculations (Weisz-Prater criteria - supplementary information) as well as experimental tests were carried out following the same criteria proposed by Madon and Boudart to ensure the absence of internal and external mass transfer limitations [39]. Prior to reaction, the samples were reduced under pure hydrogen (60 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h. The reactant mixture was obtained by flowing H2 through the saturator containing organic compound, which was kept at the specific temperature required to obtain a H2/model compound molar ratio of 60 (phenol = 74 °C; m-cresol = 87 °C; xylenol = 90 °C; anisole = 44 °C). To avoid condensation, all lines were heated at 200 °C. The reaction products were analyzed by GC-MS (Agilent Technologies 7890 A), using an HP-Innowax capillary column connected to a flame-ionization detector (FID) and Porapak Q column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for quantification. The catalysts were evaluated under different W/F (catalyst mass (g)/mass flow rate (g/h) of oxygenated compound) varying the amount of catalyst. The first injection was carried out after 5 min of time-on-stream (TOS), where minimal deactivation of the catalyst was expected. The conversion, product selectivity and HDO reaction rate, were determined by the following Eqs. (2–4): (2) Conversion % = mol 0 feed − mol feed mol 0 feed × 100 (3) Selectivity % = mol i mol 0 feed − mol feed × 100 (4) Rate HDO mmol g − 1 cat min − 1 = Y x F W where mol0 feed and molfeed are the number of initial and after reaction moles of the organic feed respectively, mol i is the number of moles of a given i product and W is the catalyst mass (g). The HDO reaction rate was calculated considering only the yield of deoxygenated compounds formed (Y) in each reaction (phenol: benzene; m-cresol: toluene; anisole: benzene, cyclohexane, cyclohexene). In order to avoid mass transfer effects, the reaction rate was calculated at low conversion. Therefore, the reaction rates for all molecules were calculated from the conversion versus W/F curves by interpolation to X = 5 %. To do this, extrapolation was made to the point of X = 0 and, from this line, the W/F and the yields of the different products for each molecule were determined to calculate the HDO reaction rates. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 shows the composition and the surface area of the catalysts. The SiO2 loading was close to the nominal values except for the sample containing 10 wt%. The Pd content was around 2 wt% for all catalysts. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. S1. All catalysts exhibited isotherms of type IV characteristic of mesoporous materials, with capillary condensation accompanied by hysteresis [40]. Pd/CeO2 and Pd/2SiCeO2 presented a hysteresis loop of type H3, characteristic of non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles. On the other hand, Pd/6SiCeO2 and Pd/10SiCeO2 catalysts showed an H5 type hysteresis, which is typical of certain pore structures containing both open and partially blocked mesopores [40]. The same type of isotherms has been reported in the literature for ceria-silica materials [41]. Therefore, the addition of silica caused a significant change in the porosity of ceria, as observed by the N2 adsorption results. The surface areas calculated from these isotherms significantly increased as the silica content increased from 56 m2/g (Pd/CeO2) to 136 m2/g (Pd/10SiCeO2) and the pores volume went from 0.042 to 0.167 cm3/g. The same result was reported in the literature [42–44]. The X-ray diffractograms of all catalysts showed the lines characteristic of ceria with cubic structure (JCPDS 34–0394) (Fig. S2). The addition of silica to ceria did not shift their lines to higher values of 2θ, thus indicating that a ceria-silica solid solution was not obtained. However, the increase in the concentration of silica caused a broadening of the lines relative to CeO2 and a decrease in their intensities, suggesting a decrease in the crystallite diameter of CeO2. The crystallite size of CeO2 strongly decreased as the Si content increased from 11.0 nm (Pd/CeO2) to 1.9 nm (Pd/10SiCeO2). The diffraction lines of PdO were not observed, which is likely due to the low concentration of this metal or the high dispersion of PdO particles. The lattice parameter of CeO2 was also calculated from the (111) reflections and are listed in Table 1. The calculated value for CeO2 was close to the one reported in the literature [45]. Furthermore, the addition of silica did not significantly change the lattice parameter of CeO2, confirming that a ceria-silica solid solution was not formed. Therefore, the addition of SiO2 resulted in an increase in the surface area and a decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size, without any change in the lattice parameter. The oxygen vacancies concentration for the different catalysts after reduction at 300 °C was measured by OSC and OSCC analyses and is reported in Table 2. The values obtained from OSCC analysis are very close of those obtained from OSC and the same tendency is observed. The addition of silica strongly increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies, with an increase of 5-fold between Pd/CeO2 (226/223 µmol/gCeO2) and Pd/10SiCeO2 (1284/1059 µmol/gCeO2). Even considering the changes in surface area, the density of oxygen vacancies also increased with the addition of silica. It is important to highlight that the density of oxygen vacancies depends strongly on the surface area. Published data show oxygen vacancies concentrations per surface area for materials such as bare CeO₂, Pt/CeO₂, and CeₓZr₁₋ₓO₂ ranging from 3.2 to 10 µmol/m², depending on the specific surface area of the sample (Table S1) [46–50]. For example, a Pt/Ce₀.₇₅Zr₀.₂₅O₂ catalyst with a surface area of 72 m²/g exhibits a total oxygen vacancy concentration of 723 µmol/g, corresponding to approximately 10 µmol/m². In our work, the increase in the density of oxygen vacancies with the addition of Si to ceria is likely associated with the decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size [27]. In situ XANES experiments were also carried out to access the evolution of oxygen vacancies formation in the ceria support during reduction of Pd/CeO2 and Pd/6SiCeO2 catalysts. This is a commonly used technique to determinate the concentration of Ce4+ and Ce3+ species under different catalysts treatments [51]. As it was mentioned in the introduction, the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ species is followed by the creation of oxygen vacancies to keep the charge balance, and thus this technique may give an indirect measure of the concentration of oxygen vacancies [52–54]. Fig. 1a and b shows the Ce LIII-edge XANES spectra of Pd/CeO2 and Pd/6SiCeO2 catalysts recorded before and during reduction under 5 % H2/He mixture from 25 to 300 °C. The XANES spectra of references (Ce4+: CeO2; Ce3+: Ce(OH)CO3) are also shown in Fig. 1e. The XANES spectra of both calcined samples exhibited two peaks (B and C) [32,52] similar to the ones observed on CeO2, indicating that they contain mainly Ce4+ species. When the Pd/CeO2 catalyst was reduced at 300 °C, the XANES spectrum remained practically unchanged, with a slight decrease in the intensities of peaks B and C and the appearance of a shoulder in the low energy region, suggesting that the extent of reduction of ceria was limited. The same result was reported by Teles et al. [29] for Pd/CeO2 catalyst reduced at 300 °C. However, the intensities of the peaks B and C decreases, and a new peak B0 appears after reduction of Pd/6SiCeO2 catalyst at 300 °C. This result reveals that the addition of Si promoted the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ species, which is accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies. The evolution of the fraction of Ce4+ and Ce3+ species during the reduction was estimated via a linear combination analysis of XANES spectra using the references (Fig. 1c and d). The fraction of Ce3+ species after reduction at 300 °C was 10 % for Pd/CeO2 and 38 % for Pd/6SiCeO2, which confirms that the addition of Si promotes the reduction of ceria and the formation of oxygen vacancies, as observed by OSC/OSCC measurements. Indeed, these Ce4+ to Ce3+ reduction degrees closely match those estimated by OSCC measurements, based on the comparison between the amount of CO consumed and the theoretical amount of CO required for the complete reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ (10 and 30 % for Pd/CeO2 and Pd/6SiCeO2, catalysts, respectively). The acid-base properties of the supports were investigated by the dehydration of cyclohexanol reaction [55]. The dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene is catalyzed by the acid sites and thus, the reaction rate of dehydration of cyclohexanol (DHA) gives information about the acidity of the catalysts. Table 3 lists the rate of DHA of the Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts. The addition of silica only slightly increased the reaction rate of dehydration (1.1 ×10−3 to 5.4 ×10−3 mmol/(gcatal.min)). However, the dehydration rate over Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts was much lower than that over a Pd/Nb2O5 catalyst (6.8 mmol/(gcatal.min)) [5]. The yield to cyclohexene was very low (0.1 %), and the main products formed were cyclohexanone (3–6 %) and phenol (6–11 %) as shown in Table S2. This result indicates that the acidity of Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts is too low to carry out the dehydration of cyclohexanol, while dehydrogenation reactions dominated. Table 3 also lists the Pd dispersion calculated for Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts using the dehydrogenation of cyclohexane as a probe reaction. The Pd dispersion was approximately the same for all Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts (26–32 %), regardless of the silica content. The Pd particle size calculated from DPd varied between 3.5 – 4.3 nm. The low contrast between Pd particles and ceria support makes it difficult to determine the Pd particle size distribution. However, the TEM images of the reduced Pd/10SiCeO2 catalyst showed the presence of Pd particles around 2–3 nm ( Fig. 2), which agrees very well with the particle size calculated by the probe reaction (3.5 nm). 3.2 Relationships between texture/structure/morphology and oxygen storage capacity of silica-doped ceria Doping of ceria with silica produces important textural, structural and morphological modifications [31,41–44,56,57–59]. It has been proposed that the addition of silica to ceria increases the surface area and the extent of reduction of ceria whereas the crystallite size of CeO2 decreases. However, the reason for these modifications is still quite controversial in the literature and it has been attributed to: (i) the formation of a Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 phase after reduction at high temperature [42]; (ii) the formation of a silica-ceria solid solution [42]; (iii) the formation of finely dispersed ceria particles on the surface of the spherical silica particles [41,58]; and (iv) the formation of Ce-O-Si bonds [44]. Rocchini et al. [42] investigated the effect of the addition of different amounts of Si (0 – 5.5 wt% Si) on the structure, morphology and oxygen storage behavior of ceria. Increasing silica content significantly increased the surface area (from 77 to 168 m2/g) and the extent of reduction of ceria when treated in 5 % H2/Ar mixture at 1000 °C. The diffractograms of the samples calcined at 1000 °C revealed the presence of CeO2 with cubic structure. No evidence of Si insertion into the ceria structure was observed. The authors proposed that the calcined samples were represented by a physical mixture of CeO2 crystallites and amorphous SiO2, and a solid solution between silica and ceria was not formed. After reduction at high temperature (1000 °C), Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 phase was formed. The reoxidation of this phase produced ceria particles with small size, which should be responsible for the high oxygen storage capacity. Chang et al. [58] carried out TEM analyses of CeO2.SiO2 samples (Ce/Si = 1) prepared by the sol-gel method. The TEM images revealed the presence of a mixture of microspheres and irregular clusters. The silica microspheres had CeO2 particles with sizes of 2–3 nm deposited on their surfaces. The clusters were composed by aggregates of CeO2 particles. Khalil et al. [41] also observed the formation of finely dispersed ceria particles on the surface of the spherical silica particles prepared by the Stöber method. Hu et al. [44] synthesized xCeO2.(1-x)SiO2 (x = 0.00, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.00) samples by the sol-gel method using hexahydrated cerium (ΙΙΙ) nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (C8H20O4Si) as precursors. The diffractograms detected only the diffractions characteristic of CeO2 with cubic structure, while the diffractions of SiO2 were not observed. The average crystallite size of CeO2 decreased with the increase in SiO2 content, whereas the CeO2 lattice parameter remained constant, indicating that a solid solution was not formed. The increase in SiO2 content also strongly increased the surface area (from 20 to 260 m2/g). According to the authors, this increase observed in the specific surface area of ceria with silica doping was due to the formation of Ce-O-Si bonds, which would make the condensation reactions difficult during calcination, inhibiting sintering/crystallization. In our work, the characteristics diffractions lines of ceria did not shift to higher 2θ positions with the addition of Si4+ cation (0.40 Å). Such a shift is observed when a cation such as Zr4+ (0.72 Å) with smaller ionic radius than Ce4+ (0.97 Å) is substituted into the lattice of ceria, which leads to the formation of a solid solution [31]. Therefore, the diffractograms suggest that a silica-ceria solid solution was not formed (Fig. S2). Furthermore, the lines typical of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 phase were not detected either, which is likely due to the low reduction temperature used in our work. The increase in surface area could be due to the presence of highly dispersed ceria particles over silica as it has been reported in the literature [41,58,59]. In order to obtain information about the morphology and spatial chemical composition distribution of our catalysts, STEM and EDS studies were carried out and the results are shown in Fig. S3. The bright-field STEM image of reduced Pd/10SiCeO2 catalyst did not show any evidence for the presence of microspheres of SiO2 coated by CeO2 particles. In fact, it revealed the formation of aggregates of CeO2 particles (Fig. S3a). The chemical mapping analysis demonstrated that cerium and silicon atoms were uniformly distributed and they occupied the same regions, indicating a close contact between them (Figs. S3 b-d). Thus, the question still remains: why the addition of silica decreases the ceria crystallite size and increases the surface area? In our preparation method, SiO2 is solubilized with NaOH, producing orthosilicic acid. Furthermore, the addition of NH4OH to a solution containing (NH4)2.Ce(NO3)6·6 H2O might lead to the formation of cerium oxyhydroxide clusters (Fig. S4) [60]. When these solutions are mixed, cerium oxyhydroxide clusters and orthosilicic acid are expected to interact through their hydroxyl groups. During calcination, dehydration occurs but the presence of silica inhibits the polycondensation of cerium oxyhydroxide clusters, leading to the formation of smaller CeO2 particles and amorphous SiO2 in close contact, which explains the high surface area of Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts without the formation of a silica-ceria solid solution. Therefore, the formation of Ce-O-Si bonds is responsible for the high surface area and, consequently, the high oxygen mobility of the Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts. 3.3 HDO of model molecules over Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts 3.3.1 Phenol The conversion of phenol and the yields for the different products as a function of residence time (W/F) in the HDO reaction of phenol over Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 and Tables S3-S6. Increasing W/F led to an increase in phenol conversion. Table 4 reports the reaction rate for HDO of phenol over Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts calculated at low conversion (5 %) from Fig. 3. This is required to compare the performance of catalysts under kinetic regime. Increasing the silica content increased the reaction rate for HDO of phenol. The distribution of products was quite similar for the four catalysts, with the formation of cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol and benzene (deoxygenated product formed). Increasing W/F affected the distribution of the various products differently. In general, an increase in the yield for benzene was observed, while the yield for cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone reached a maximum and then decreased with increasing W/F. The performance of Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts for HDO of two other molecules containing hydroxyl group (m-cresol and xylenol) was also evaluated and the results are discussed next. 3.3.2 m-cresol The curves of m-cresol conversion and product yield as a function of W/F are presented in Fig. 4 and the data reported in Tables S7-S10. The m-cresol conversion increased as residence time increased. The reaction rate for HDO of m-cresol was calculated at low conversion (5 %) from the curves of Fig. 4 and the results obtained are reported in Table 4. The Pd/10SiCeO2 catalyst had the highest HDO reaction rate, which followed the order: Pd/CeO2 ≈ Pd/2SiCeO2 < Pd/6SiCeO2 < Pd/10SiCeO2. This was the same trend observed for the HDO of phenol. The addition of silica to ceria increased the HDO reaction rate over Pd/10SiCeO2 by a factor of 2.5 in comparison to the Pd/CeO2 catalyst. Toluene, 3-methylcyclohexanone (m-ONE) and 3-methylcyclohexanol (m-OL) were the main products formed. Small amounts of m-cyclohexane and m-cyclohexene were also observed at complete conversion of m-cresol. Trace amounts of methane were detected over all catalysts except for Pd/2SiCeO2 at 100 % of m-cresol conversion. The yield to m-ONE and m-OL went through a maximum whereas the yield to toluene continuously increased as the residence time increased. The comparison between yields to different products at low conversion reveal that the addition of silica to ceria strongly increased the formation of toluene. Pd/10SiCeO2 had a selectivity to toluene that was 2.5-fold higher than that of the undoped ceria catalyst. The selectivity towards toluene followed the order: Pd/CeO2 ≈ Pd/2SiCeO2 < Pd/6SiCeO2 < Pd/10SiCeO2. Therefore, these results revealed that the doping of ceria with silica significantly promoted the formation of deoxygenated products from m-cresol. Comparing with results from the literature is complicated because the reaction conditions are not always the same (temperature, pressure, composition of the reaction mixture), which significantly affects the reaction. In addition, different catalysts have been used, which also makes comparison difficult since the nature of the metal and the support plays an important role in the HDO reaction. Therefore, we selected some works from the literature that used reaction conditions similar to those employed in our work for the comparison and discussion of our results. Table 5 reports some results from the literature [9,61–68] on the HDO reaction of m-cresol performed at low conversion. The product distribution strongly depends on the catalyst. Hydrogenation metals such as Pd and Pt supported on inert materials such as silica exhibit higher selectivity to the hydrogenated product (3-methylcyclohexanone), while metals such as Ru and Ni are more selective to the deoxygenated compounds as well as products from C-C hydrogenolysis. Higher selectivity toward toluene is obtained for catalyst presenting metal/oxophilic sites interfaces, as already demonstrated in the literature for other model compounds such as phenol and anisole. 3.3.3 Xylenol The conversion and the yields for the different products in the HDO reaction of xylenol over Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts are listed Table S11. Concerning product distribution, xylene, 3,4-dimethylcyclohexanone and methane were mainly produced, with minor amounts of toluene, benzene, phenol and 3,4-dimethylcyclohexanol. The reaction rate for HDO of xylenol over Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts at 5 % of conversion are listed in Table 4. As it was observed for phenol and m-cresol, the reaction rate for HDO of xylenol increased as the Si content increased. The HDO reactions of phenol and m-cresol reaction have been extensively studied in the literature [6,7,9,17,18,63,68,69]. According to the mechanism based on the tautomerization of phenol and m-cresol [7,9,17,69], the tautomer formed may react via two different reaction pathways, depending on the type of the support. The hydrogenation of the ring produces cyclohexanone/3-methylcyclohexanone and cyclohexanol/3-methylcyclohexanol that occurs mainly on Pd/SiO2 and Pd/CeO2 catalysts [9,17,68], which agrees very well with our results. The other route involves the hydrogenation of the carbonyl group of the tautomer to an unsaturated alcohol that is rapidly converted to benzene/toluene by dehydration. This reaction pathway is characteristic of oxophilic supports such as ZrO2, TiO2 and Nb2O5 [7,9,17,69]. The strong interaction between the oxygen from the phenolic molecule and the oxophilic support may also promote the direct cleavage of the C-O bond. The HDO reaction of xylenol has been less studied, and we did not find a proposal for the reaction mechanism. However, considering the similarities between the HDO mechanisms of phenol and m-cresol, we can suggest that xylenol follows the same tautomerization mechanism, in which xylenol adsorbs by the oxygen of the hydroxyl group, followed by the formation of a tautomer-intermediate. The hydrogenation of the ring produces 3,4-dimethylcyclohexanone and 3,4-dimethylcyclohexanol. The direct cleavage of the C-OH bond produces an intermediate that may be hydrogenated to xylene or it may undergo hydrogenolysis, leading to the formation of methane, toluene and benzene, a mechanism similar to the one proposed for m-cresol. 3.3.4 Anisole The HDO reaction rate was approximately the same for all catalysts, regardless the Si content (Table 4). This result suggest that the oxygen vacancy does not affect the deoxygenation activity of the catalysts for HDO of anisole. Table S12 lists the conversion, and product yield for HDO of anisole. For ceria-based catalysts, the main products obtained were methane, benzene and methoxycyclohexane, with minor formation of phenol, cyclohexane/cyclohexene, and cyclohexanone, but methanol was never observed over these catalysts. Recently, the HDO of anisole reaction was performed over Pd supported on different oxides (Pd/SiO2, Pd/CeO2, Pd/ZrO2, Pd/TiO2, Pd/Nb2O5) [9]. The main products formed in the Pd-based catalysts were benzene, phenol, methane and methanol, except for Pd/CeO2, in which the presence of methanol was not detected. This result could indicate that methanol rapidly reacts over Pd/CeO2, producing CO and H2 with further hydrogenation of CO to produce CH4. Therefore, the reaction of methanol under the same HDO reaction conditions (300 °C, H2/CH3OH molar ratio = 55) was carried out over Pd/CeO2 catalyst. Nearly complete conversion of methanol was achieved; however, the methane yield was very low, approximately 5 % for a 95 % conversion of methanol. This result confirms that methanol decomposition to CO and H2 can occur under the HDO reaction conditions used in our work, but CO is not further hydrogenated to CH4. Therefore, methane is produced via demethylation reaction pathway. In the present work, a small amount of CO was also observed in the TCD, indicating that methanol could be formed during HDO of anisole over Pd/CeO2 catalyst, but methane is not produced by this route as previously discussed. Therefore, these results suggest that demethylation is the main reaction pathway on ceria-based catalysts. According to Tan et al. [70], the demethylation of anisole produces a phenoxy intermediate species that can be hydrogenated to phenol or produce benzene through the cleavage of the C-O bond of this intermediate. However, the Pd/CeO2 catalyst has low activity for the hydrogenation of the C-O bond of the tautomer [15,29]. Therefore, benzene could be produced by the cleavage of the C-O bond of the phenoxy species formed. Teles et al. [9] performed DRIFTS measurements during anisole adsorption at different temperatures on the surface of different supported palladium catalysts (Pd/CeO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/Nb2O5). The spectra of the Pd/CeO2 catalyst exhibited a complex set of bands, characteristic among others, of the adsorption of the phenoxide species. While for oxophilic catalysts such as Pd/Nb2O5, the appearance of a characteristic band of methanol is observed with increasing temperature, only characteristic bands of the aromatic ring and CAr-O remain evident in the Pd/CeO2 spectra. These results reinforced the proposal that demethylation remains the main route on this catalyst, with subsequent cleavage of the CAr-O* bond of the phenoxy species to form benzene. The hydrogenation of the ring from the anisole molecule with the formation of methoxycyclohexane is another reaction pathway observed on the ceria-based catalysts, as it has already been reported in the literature. A reaction mechanism for the HDO of anisole over different supported Pd catalysts is presented by Teles et al. [9]. However, the product distribution was approximately the same for all catalysts, regardless of the Si content. 3.3.5 The role of oxygen vacancies on the HDO of model molecules containing different functional groups (hydroxyl and methoxy) According to literature, the deoxygenation activity is strongly dependent on the type of the support [15,17,21]. However, the nature of active sites for deoxygenation is still controversial. It has been proposed that the deoxygenation reaction occurs at the interface between metal particles and: (i) acid sites; (ii) oxophilic sites; (iii) oxygen vacancies. For the HDO of phenol and m-cresol, the acid sites of the support could promote the dehydration of cyclohexanol/methylcyclohexanol to cyclohexene/methylcyclohexene followed by hydrogenation to cyclohexane/methylcyclohexane over metal sites. In our work, cyclohexene/methylcyclohexene and cyclohexane/methylcyclohexane were not formed on HDO reaction of phenol and m-cresol, indicating that the deoxygenation reaction does not take place on the acid sites of this support. Furthermore, the tests of cyclohexanol dehydration (Table 3 and S1) carried out with these catalysts did not detect significant formation of cyclohexene either, which confirms that this reaction pathway does not occur over Pd/SiCeO2 catalysts. Therefore, the concentration of acid sites is still too low to be able to dehydrate cyclohexanol/methylcyclohexanol formed to cyclohexene/methylcyclohexene, as it is observed in the literature for supports with higher acidity [9]. Then, the acid sites do not participate on the HDO of phenolic molecules in gas phase. This is also valid for the HDO of anisole reaction, in which only small amounts of methylcyclohexene and methylcyclohexane were formed. Several authors have reported that oxophilic sites located at the perimeter of metal particles play an important role in the deoxygenation of phenolic molecules such as phenol and m-cresol, and to a lesser extent anisole [5,71–73]. The strong interaction between the oxygen atom of the phenolic molecule and the oxophilic site reduces the energy barrier necessary for the cleavage of the C-O bond, promoting the deoxygenation pathway. Recently, it has been demonstrated that the interaction between the oxygen and supports such as SiO2 and CeO2 is very weak due to their low oxophilicity [11,15,74]. Since the XRD experiments in the present work did not detect the insertion of Si into the CeO2 lattice with the formation of a solid solution, it is not expected that there is any change in the oxophilicity of these Si doped ceria supports. Some works proposed that the oxygen vacancies are responsible for the activation of C-O bonds, promoting the deoxygenation. However, the studies about the effect of oxygen vacancies on the deoxygenation activity usually involves reducible oxides, which provide oxygen vacancies but also oxophilic sites [25,29,75,76]. For example, some works showed an increase in deoxygenation activity, when using ceria doped with zirconia as a support, in which zirconia induces the creation of oxygen vacancies, but is also an oxophilic support. Then, it is quite difficult to distinguish between both effects (oxophilicity and oxygen vacancies). In our work, both SiO2 and CeO2 exhibit low oxophilicity and therefore, its effect on HDO reaction is not relevant. The OSC and OSCC experiments revealed an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies with the increase of the amount of Si. Fig. 5 shows the reaction rate for HDO of phenol, m-cresol, xylenol and anisole and the concentration of oxygen vacancies as a function of the silica content. The addition of silica increased both the concentration of oxygen vacancies and the reaction rate for HDO of phenol, m-cresol, and xylenol, whereas the rate for HDO of anisole remained approximately constant, regardless of the silica content. Comparing the results obtained for HDO of phenol (hydroxyl group) and anisole (methoxy group), a higher yield to benzene was observed from anisole (around 34 %) compared to phenol (around 10 %). This is quite surprising since the reaction pathway for both molecules goes through a phenoxy species as intermediate. Therefore, similar formation of benzene should be expected for both molecules, unless the active sites are not the same. Recently, we investigated the mode and strength of adsorption of the different molecules (phenol, m-cresol, anisole and binary mixtures) on the surface of various catalysts (Pd/CeO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/Nb2O5) by DRIFTS analysis upon adsorption and desorption [9]. For Pd/CeO2 catalyst, the spectrum of adsorbed phenol is characteristic of the different vibrational modes of phenoxy species (υ(C−Hring), 3069 cm−1; υ(CCring), 1594 and 1482 cm−1); υ(CAr−OH), 1275 cm−1), produced by the dissociative adsorption of phenol over the support. The spectra of adsorbed anisole on Pd/CeO2 show the bands corresponding to the aromatic ring between 1500 and 1490 cm−1. There are also two bands at 1296 and 1245 cm−1 related to υ(CAr−OCH3) vibrations and an intense band observed at 1035 cm−1 that corresponds to the υ(H3C−O) vibration of the methoxy group. There is an intense band at 1564 cm−1 that correlates with an asymmetric υ(OCO) stretching mode corresponding to a vibration that looks like formate species, with the oxygen of anisole molecule bonding to the Ce cation. The DRIFTS spectra with the binary mixtures (phenol + anisole; m-cresol + anisole) revealed that m-cresol adsorbs more strongly on the catalyst surface and reacts more readily than anisole. These results confirm that phenol and anisole adsorb on different sites and explain the invariance of the anisole HDO reaction rate with respect to vacancy concentration. Thus, it is reasonable to suggest that the active sites for the adsorption of phenolic compounds and anisole are different. The phenolic compounds adsorb on the oxygen vacancies of the support, which explain the dependence of the reaction rate of the molecules containing a hydroxyl group on the concentration of oxygen vacancies. In the case of anisole, this molecule does not adsorb on the oxygen vacancies likely due to steric hindrance caused by the methoxy group. Instead, it likely adsorbs on less confined Ce cations close to the Pd metallic particles, so that the variation of the concentration of oxygen vacancies does not affect the rate of HDO of anisole. Therefore, these results revealed that the oxygen vacancies promoted the cleavage of the C-OH bond of the phenolic molecules and the formation of deoxygenated product. However, the presence of one and two methyl groups bonded to the aromatic ring increased the selectivity to deoxygenated products ( Fig. 6). For Pd/10SiCeO2, the selectivity to deoxygenated products was 60.1 % for xylenol, which is higher than that for m-cresol (46.8 %) and phenol (9.5 %). These results suggests that the addition of an electron donor to the ring such as methyl group promotes the cleavage of the Carom – OH bond. Therefore, initially, the phenolic compound adsorbs on the oxygen vacancy of ceria support by the oxygen of its hydroxyl group. In the case of phenol molecule, the oxygen vacancies close to the metal particles have a low capacity to break the strong Carom – OH bond and then, it is preferentially hydrogenated to m-cyclohexanone. For m-cresol and xylenol, the presence of an electron donor (methyl group) on the aromatic ring reduces the energy barrier necessary for the cleavage of the Carom – OH bond, promoting the formation of deoxygenated products. A Scheme for the reaction mechanism of HDO of m-cresol over the Pd/xSiCeO2 catalysts with different Si contents is shown in Fig. 7. The m-cresol molecule adsorbs through the oxygen of hydroxyl group on the oxygen vacancy of the support close to the metal particle. Then, the C-O bond is broken and toluene is desorbed while the oxygen vacancy is replenished. The oxygen vacancy is regenerated by reduction of the support with hydrogen adsorbed on the surface of metal particle, restarting the redox cycle (upper mechanism). For the silica-dopped ceria catalysts, a larger amount of oxygen vacancies is produced, increasing the deoxygenation activity (lower mechanism). A similar reaction mechanism is observed for phenol and xylenol. 4 Conclusions The addition of silica to ceria interfered with the formation of CeO2 crystallites, resulting in a significant change in the porosity of ceria and an increased surface area. Increasing the silica content increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies. However, doping ceria with silica did not vary the lattice parameters of CeO2, indicating that a silica-ceria solid solution was not formed. The results demonstrated that the increase in the density of oxygen vacancies is likely due to the decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size, The reaction between cerium oxyhydroxide clusters and orthosilicic acid during the synthesis inhibited the polycondensation of cerium oxyhydroxide clusters during calcination, producing small CeO2 particles. The addition of silica increased both the concentration of oxygen vacancies and the reaction rate for HDO of phenol, m-cresol, and xylenol, whereas the rate for HDO of anisole remained approximately constant. These results reveal that the oxygen vacancies promote the cleavage of the C-OH bond of the phenolic molecules and the formation of deoxygenated products. Furthermore, the presence of an electron donor (methyl group) on the aromatic ring reduces the energy barrier necessary for the cleavage of the Carom – OH bond, promoting the formation of deoxygenated products. However, the HDO of anisole is not affected by the oxygen vacancies. In fact, anisole adsorbs on the Ce cation close to the Pd metallic particles and then, it does not depend on the concentration of oxygen vacancies. A reaction mechanism for HDO of m-cresol was proposed based on the adsorption of m-cresol molecule through the oxygen of hydroxyl group on the oxygen vacancy of the support close to the metal particle. Then, the C-O bond is broken and toluene is desorbed while the oxygen vacancy is replenished. The oxygen vacancy is regenerated by reduction of the support with hydrogen adsorbed on the surface of metal particle, restarting the redox cycle. A similar reaction mechanism is observed for phenol and xylenol. CRediT authorship contribution statement Liying Liu: Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. coredata.dc:description: This work studies the effect of oxygen vacancies in a silica-doped ceria support on the mechanism of HDO reaction of phenol, m-cresol, xylenol and anisole over Pd-based catalysts. Increasing the silica content increased the density of oxygen vacancies due to the decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size. The addition of silica also promoted the reaction rate for HDO of phenolic compounds, whereas the rate for HDO of anisole remained approximately constant. These results revealed that the oxygen vacancies promoted the cleavage of the C-OH bond of phenolic molecules. Moreover, the presence of an electron donor on the aromatic ring reduces the energy barrier necessary for the cleavage of the Carom – OH bond. In the case of anisole, this molecule adsorbs on the Ce cations close to the metallic particles and then, the variation of the concentration of oxygen vacancies does not affect the rate of HDO.
